nodes.bodyText: I don't think you need this nor the previous line.

To potentially clarify, I think you need this in general (the query should only return published workflows) but I think this is currently unused which means that this might be returning unpublished content which is not good.
As I read it, the next line does do the isPublished, so I think these lines are redundant (and not even used)
For line 47/51, was like this, but message is wrong; not a token type but a SourceControl
Suggest finals, except for line 192, which you can't.

On further reflection, I don't think this is right. If the user specifies a descriptorType, you should return all the the workflows that match the descriptorType. If none match, e.g., because the descriptorType doesn't exist, then the query should return no results. Instead you're ignoring the query element.
I think you should short-circuit things and move this (or the shortened version) to the beginning of ToolsApiServiceImpl.toolsGet -- if there is a descriptorType query param and it doesn't resolve to a valid descriptor, just return an empty list.
In addition, you could use that DescriptorType to skip tools per my other suggestion.

This is nit-picking, but this is a very long condition and hard to understand

You already know if the descriptorLanguage has been found by virtue of it being null or not. I don't think you need the descriptorLanguageFound variable, although you can argue it enhances readability.
With enums, you can use ==

I would suggest two nested if statements for readability. But that's my bias.

Yeah the name and how it's being used doesn't match completely.
The user provides the descriptorType which could be null,  a string that matches one of the languages we support, or a string that doesn't match. I set descriptorLanguageFound to be true unless we are unable to match a string with the language we support. So, if they didn't provide one (null) or it matches, it will stay true and the tools/workflows will be added.
I will try to improve the readability since it is confusing.

Ah, I see, so I was wrong about line 316 -- it would still execute...
I would suggest if there is a an invalid descriptor language, just short-circuit and return Collections.emptyList(). Then it simplifies your logic downstream.
This could go inside the if on line 301, where you know descriptorType is not null. More from a readability perspective
You always want to do this even if descriptorLanguage is not found.
